messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-05-31T15:38:02Z
## Message ID: 20190531-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-05-31T15:20Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the HSS with activity ID  2019-05-28T19:30:00-HSS-001.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-05-31T15:20:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 22, 2019 - May 28, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-05-29T20:43:36Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-05-22T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-05-28T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190529-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

A coronal hole high speed stream was detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2019-05-28.  The solar wind speed has reached values of ~550 km/s on 2019-05-29.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-05-29T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-06-04T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There is currently an active region visible on the solar surface as seen from the STEREO A EUVI images that has potential for flares or CME activity.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 15, 2019 - May 21, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-05-22T22:08:46Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-05-15T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-05-21T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190522-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-05-18 and 2019-05-20.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~450 km/s on 2019-05-18
and ~650 km/s on 2019-05-21.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-05-22T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-05-28T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no active regions currently visible at the available imagery of the sun's surface, although there are two active regions that have rotated off the west limb as seen from SDO imagery that might produce some CME activity.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-05-23. 


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 08, 2019 - May 14, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-05-16T21:53:31Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-05-08T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-05-14T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190516-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period.  There were 3 C-type CMEs (see details below).   Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the CME starting on 2019-05-08T04:00Z may impact STEREO A at 2019-05-10T14:04Z and OSIRIS-REx (glancing blow) at 2019-05-11T16:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20190508-AL-001).   STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the CME arrival around 2019-05-10T07:00Z.  

Simulations also indicated that the leading edge of 2 S-types (<500 km/s) CMEs that started on 2019-05-10T19:09Z and 2019-05-11T02:39Z, would reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2019-05-14T23:50Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20190511-AL-001).  

Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=7 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=7 occurred during the synoptic period of 2019-05-14T06:00Z-09:00Z (see notifications 20190514-AL-001, 20190514-AL-002, and 20190514-AL-003).  This strong geomagnetic storm could be associated with the arrival detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2019-05-13T22:06Z of the 2 S-type CMEs described above or another transient that was not visible on the available imagery.  

There was another CME arrival detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2019-05-10T16:55Z.  This disturbance could be associated with the arrival of the S-type CME that started on 2019-05-07T04:42Z.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-05-11T20:20Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated to the CME arrival detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2019-05-10T16:55Z described above (see notifications 20190511-AL-002 and 20190511-AL-003).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the CME activity and the elevated energetic electrons fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2019-05-12T19:54Z     ~528            C               -15/-15               26                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
2019-05-13T16:09Z     ~594            C                10/-13               27                          STEREO A, SOHO                    


Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2019-05-08T04:00Z     ~790            C               -75/-12               32                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-05-15T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-05-21T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming period.  There is still some flare activity originating from the active region 12741. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week due to the possible arrival of several CMEs that started on 2019-05-12 and 2019-05-13, respectively.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-05-14T12:41:33Z
## Message ID: 20190514-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 7 (strong) during the synoptic period 2019-05-14T06:00Z to 2019-05-14T09:00Z. 

The cause of the storm is unclear, it could be due to either a transient effect or an early arrival of a CME. The CMEs with start times 2019-05-10T19:09Z and 2019-05-11T02:39Z are potential candidates.  

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-05-14T03:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes: 




NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-05-11T20:45:34Z
## Message ID: 20190511-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-05-11T20:20Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the interplanetary shock starting at 2019-05-10T16:55Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-05-11T20:20:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs (Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-05-11T14:58:24Z
## Message ID: 20190511-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: S-type CME detected by STEREO A. 

Start time of the event: 2019-05-10T19:09Z.

Estimated speed: ~471 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 24 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 10/-5 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2019-05-10T19:09:00-CME-001

2: S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2019-05-11T02:39Z.

Estimated speed: ~362 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 28 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 2/0 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2019-05-11T02:39:00-CME-001

 
Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CMEs will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2019-05-14T23:50Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-3 (below minor).

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 01, 2019 - May 07, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-05-08T19:01:10Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-05-01T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-05-07T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190508-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period. There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below). Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the CMEs starting on 2019-05-03T18:36Z and 2019-05-03T23:36Z may impact Spitzer at 2019-05-06T09:29Z, STEREO A at 2019-05-07T04:46Z, Mars at 2019-05-08T15:30Z (plus minus 7 hours) and have a glancing blow to OSIRIS-REx at around 2019-05-07T10:00Z (see notification 20190504-AL-001). STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the CME arrival around 2019-05-06T22:20Z.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2019-05-01T21:00Z to 2019-05-02T06:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2019-05-01. The solar wind speed reached values of ~560 km/s on 2019-05-02.

The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-05-03T17:25Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES are associated with the coronal hole high speed stream on 2019-05-01 described above (see notifications 20190503-AL-001 and 20190503-AL-002).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2019-05-03T18:36Z     ~863            C              -129/-12               25                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2019-05-03T23:36Z     ~776            C               -75/12                31                          SOHO, STEREO A                    

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-05-08T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-05-14T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. There are two active regions (12740 and 12741) currently visible at the available imagery of the sun's surface which have potential for flares and CMEs and have been active for the past few days. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.

ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2019-05-08T04:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~790 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 32 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -75/-12 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-05-03T17:40:16Z
## Message ID: 20190503-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-05-03T17:25Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2019-05-01T12:41Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-05-03T17:25:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 24, 2019 - April 30, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-05-01T19:24:43Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-04-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-04-30T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190501-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period. There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below), but they were not directed to any location of interest.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-04-24. Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2019-04-24.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2019-04-28T08:00Z     ~595            C               165/-3                28                          STEREO A                          
2019-04-30T14:24Z     ~989            C              -176/0                 19                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-05-01T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-05-07T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. There are two active regions currently visible from STEREO A EUVI imagery that have been producing CME activity (see details above) and have potential for flares. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-05-02. 

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
